variant.question: According to the European Regulation on Air Operations, for Commercial Air Transport operations, when planning an IFR flight, an operator should select two destination alternate aerodromes when..

options.text: no meteorological information is available.
the two destination alternate aerodromes are isolated and 1 hour away from each other.
the runway at the intended destination aerodrome is contaminated.
the duration of the planned flight from take-off to landing exceeds 6 hours.

variant.question: When would you choose 2 IFR destinations on your flight plan

options.text: When there is no Meteorological information at the destination
When there is no Meteorological information at the departure aerodrome
When the destination has only one runway
When the destination is more than 2 hours or 400NM from land

variant.question: The minimum time track is a track defined for:

options.text: a given travel.
a period of 24 hours.
a period of 12 hours.
aircraft flying in MNPS airspace.

variant.question: The minimum time track is a track defined for:

options.text: A route that gives the shortest  flight time from departure to destination.
A period of 12 hours
Aircraft flying in MNPS airspace
A period of 24 hours

variant.question: What is the definition of a minimum time route?

options.text: Shortest time between dest and dep adhering to ATC restrictions.
Shortest distance between two points of a route.
Route using the least amount of fuel.
Closest diversion on route.

variant.question:
Which combination of options below best describes the factors that need to be taken into account when calculating minimum time routes? 
1.ATC restrictions 
2.Wind and meteorological conditions 
3.Straight-line distance between departure and destination points 
4.Danger, Restricted, and Prohibited areas and airspace restrictions

options.text: 3 and 4
2 and 3

variant.question: According to OPS regulations, for an IFR flight, the selection of a destination alternate is not required when

options.text: the destination is isolated.
the destination aerodrome has two runways with an ILS approach.
the duration of the planned flight does not exceed 8 hours and the weather forecast calls for VMC conditions at the destination aerodrome.
an adequate take-off alternate is available.

variant.question: With reference to ICAO Annex 6, a departure aerodrome can also be used as a:

options.text: en route and destination diversion.
take-off diversion only.
backup diversion.
take-off and en route diversion.

variant.question: A minimum time track is a

options.text: track determined according to wind conditions
spherical capable flight segment
rhumb line
great circle track

variant.question: The operator shall select at least one destination alternate aerodrome for each instrument flight rules (IFR) flight:

options.text: unless the destination aerodrome is an isolated aerodrome.

unless the duration of the planned flight from take-off to landing or, in the event of in-flight replanning in accordance with CAT.OP.MPA.150(d), the remaining flying time to destination does not exceed eight hours.
unless three separate runways are available and usable at the destination aerodrome.

unless two separate runways are available and usable at the destination aerodrome and the appropriate weather reports and/or forecasts for the destination aerodrome indicate that, for the period from one hour before until one hour after the expected time of arrival at the destination aerodrome, the ceiling will be at least 2 000 ft or circling height + 500 ft, whichever is greater, and the ground visibility will be at least 10 km or more.

variant.question: According to OPS regulations, an operator must select a take-off alternate:

options.text: if it would not be possible to return to the aerodrome of departure for meteorological or performance reasons.
when the flight duration exceeds 6 hours.
when conducting a flight over water of more than 2 hours or 400 NM, whichever is the lesser.
for an IFR flight with a single-engine aeroplane.

variant.question: In MNPS Airspace ETA changes exceeding a certain time must be reported to ATC. This time is:

options.text: 3 minutes or more.
4 minutes.
1 minute or more.
2 minutes or more.

variant.question: A turboprop aeroplane is performing an overwater flight, which takes it further than 340 NM away from land which is suitable for making an emergency landing. Normal cruising speed is 180 kts. One engine out airspeed is 155 kts. According to EASA AIR OPS:

options.text: life jackets must be available for all occupants.
life jackets and rafts must be available for all occupants.
life rafts must be available for all occupants.
life jackets or rafts are not required to be taken on board in this particular case.

variant.question: When would you have to specify 2 destination alternates?

options.text: When the weather at destination is below planning minima 1 hour before and 1 hour after ETA.
When the destination has a single runway and a single locator beacon.
When the destination has a single runway.
When the weather at destination is below planning minima 2 hours before and 1 hour after ETA.

variant.question: According to AIR OPS, the selection of a destination alternate is NOT required when:

options.text: the destination is isolated and no adequate destination alternate exists.
you have an adequate take-off alternate.
the destination aerodrome has an ILS approach for each runway.
the duration of the planned flight does not exceed 8 hours and the weather forecast calls for VMC at the destination aerodrome.

variant.question: An operator must select two destination alternates when:

options.text: the appropriate weather reports or forecasts for the destination, or any combination thereof, indicate that during a period commencing 1 hour before and ending 1 hour after the estimated time of arrival, the weather conditions will be below the applicable planning minima or when no meteorological information is available.

the appropriate weather reports or forecasts for the destination, or any combination thereof, indicate that during a period commencing 1 hour before and ending 1 hour after the estimated time of arrival, the weather conditions will be below the applicable planning minima.
no meteorological information is available.
all of the above are wrong.

variant.question: What is the reason for selecting a suitable take-off alternate aerodrome?

options.text: To ensure a safe landing can be made in case of emergency after take-off when departure aerodrome can not be used due to performance or meteorological reasons.
To ensure a safe landing can be made in case of emergency after take-off when destination aerodrome can not be used due to performance or meteorological reasons.
A suitable take-off alternate aerodrome serves as a stopover for refuelling purposes on long distance flights.
Selection of a suitable take-off alternate aerodrome is always required if the planned flight time to destination is greater than 8 hours.

variant.question: You are approaching an airport with a light aircraft and a wind from the north. ATC gives you the option to land on the following runways. Which one should you choose?

options.text: 33L, a light airplane is taking off.
33R, a Helicopter is taking off.
21, A318 is taking off.
03, B777 is taking off.
